title: Elgin Marbles
summary: The Elgin Marbles (/ˈɛlɡɪn/),[1] also known as the Parthenon Marbles (Greek: Γλυπτά του Παρθενώνα), are a collection of Classical Greek marble sculptures made under the supervision of the architect and sculptor Phidias and his assistants. They were originally part of the temple of the Parthenon and other buildings on the Acropolis of Athens.[2][3] The collection is now on display in the British Museum, in the purpose-built Duveen Gallery.
